definition: newly-appointed/newly elected/new (in a political office)
abbr. for Xinjiang 新疆[Xin1 jiang1] or Singapore 新加坡[Xin1 jia1 po1]/surname Xin
new/newly/meso- (chemistry)
surname Ren/Ren County 任縣|任县[Ren2 Xian4] in Hebei

to assign/to appoint/to take up a post/office/responsibility/to let/to allow/to give free rein to/no matter (how, what etc)/classifier for terms served in office, or for spouses, girlfriends etc (as in 前任男友)

sentences.english: Stefano Pioli is the new coach now, having been in charge of Modena.
sentences.chinese: 皮奧利是他們的新任主教練，執教過摩德納。

sentences.english: The new teacher has really taken the students by storm.
sentences.chinese: 新任老師廣獲學生好評。

sentences.english: Our hilarious Ant-Man had a funny fight with Falcon.
sentences.chinese: 獵鷹和我們新任的逗逼蟻人在這裏有了場搞笑的對決。

sentences.english: The new president achieved great popularity.
Mr. Li Tieying, new President of Toy Shan Association, extended his holiday greetings to the guests.
sentences.chinese: 台山同鄉會新任會長李鐵英向來賓致以新春問候。

sentences.english: Every new executive must do the rounds of all the departments in the company.
sentences.chinese: 每次新任總管都得到所有的部門走訪一遍。

sentences.english: Mr. Li, the new chairman of the department, will speak at the meeting.
sentences.chinese: 這個部門的新任主席李先生，將在會上發言。

sentences.english: The new leader personified a new spirit of the time.
sentences.chinese: 新任領袖代表了時代的一種新精神。

sentences.english: The man with the green umbrella will be our new president .
sentences.chinese: 拿着綠傘的那個人想必是我們的新任董事長。

sentences.english: Mr. Ji Jae Ryong, the new DPRK Ambassador to China arrived in Beijing today.
sentences.chinese: 新任朝鮮駐華大使池在龍先生已於今天抵達北京。

sentences.english: The new ambassador is expected to present his credentials tomorrow.
sentences.chinese: 這位新任大使預定於明日呈遞國書。

sentences.english: The Reds' new No. 17 was also welcomed to Merseyside by former Atletico teammate Fernando Torres.
sentences.chinese: 利物浦新任17號同樣受到前馬競隊友託雷斯的歡迎。

sentences.english: He had full support of the board and its new chairman.
sentences.chinese: 他得到了菲亞特董事會和新任董事長的全力支持。

sentences.english: For the new one, Ban Ki-moon, it seems to be the environment and natural resources. Last year he threw his weight behind a declaration in Bali on climate change.
sentences.chinese: 而對於新任的潘基文，焦點似乎是在環境與資源上。

sentences.english: There is a party tonight in honour of the appoinment of the new school president, would you come?
sentences.chinese: 今晚將爲新任校長舉行餐會，你想來嗎？

sentences.english: Prime Minister AP was swore in last week.
sentences.chinese: 新任總理阿披於上週宣誓就職。

definition: to take over (as minister, manager etc)
to appoint/(job) appointment/CL:紙|纸[zhi3]
to succeed sb in a job/successor
to take office/to assume a post
to leave office
to replace/to take over (a position or post)
to take office/previous (incumbent)/predecessor
to take up a post/to start in a new job
next office holder/next to serve
to be promoted to
to leave office/to leave one's post
to ride to take up an official appointment (idiom); to take on a job with alacrity/to undertake a task
to wield (power etc)
post/position/job/duties
to appoint
to occupy a post currently/current (president etc)/incumbent/(coll.) current boyfriend (girlfriend, spouse)
